content.body: Do I understand correctly that there are no normative requirements on the user agent style sheet(s) for media documents?
I don't recall seeing any when I last looked, but that was probably five years ago at least
Thanks.
smaug: unless you have an objection to the things presented in https://github.com/whatwg/dom/pull/1009 I'm inclined to merge it as it meets all the criteria as far as I can tell
content.formatted_body: smaug: unless you have an objection to the things presented in https://github.com/whatwg/dom/pull/1009 I'm inclined to merge it as it meets all the criteria as far as I can tell

content.body: hsivonen: thanks. speculative parsing occurring when there isn't a blocking <script> is new to me
content.formatted_body: hsivonen: thanks. speculative parsing occurring when there isn't a blocking <script> is new to me

content.body: Hmm. I thought that Firefox can start speculative fetching the resources found by non-speculative parsing before the corresponding nodes end up in the DOM, but now that you say that, I need to check if that actually happens.

> <@hsivonen:mozilla.org> Hmm. I thought that Firefox can start speculative fetching the resources found by non-speculative parsing before the corresponding nodes end up in the DOM, but now that you say that, I need to check if that actually happens.

From a quick source inspection, it looks to me that Firefox can speculatively start fetching non-speculatively-found URLs before the corresponding elements end up in the DOM, but if you've not seen it when observing Firefox opaquely, I'm not 100% sure.
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @hsivonen:mozilla.org
Hmm. I thought that Firefox can start speculative fetching the resources found by non-speculative parsing before the corresponding nodes end up in the DOM, but now that you say that, I need to check if that actually happens.
From a quick source inspection, it looks to me that Firefox can speculatively start fetching non-speculatively-found URLs before the corresponding elements end up in the DOM, but if you've not seen it when observing Firefox opaquely, I'm not 100% sure.

content.body: Not sure how you'd observe this from a script, but this should happen if you have a huge scriptless document with a bunch of images.
smaug: yeah, I was wondering how specific it would be to WebKit/Chromium
content.formatted_body: smaug: yeah, I was wondering how specific it would be to WebKit/Chromium

content.body:
> <@tabatkins:matrix.org> sujaldev: Parsing is definitely hard at first! I've been deep in parsing for a long time (I wrote the CSS Syntax spec), so my difficulty judgement is a bit skewed. ^_^ Which should be an indicator of how hard *layout* is, tho.

do you have any suggestions on how I could make something simpler for the layout part? (assuming its possible)
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @tabatkins:matrix.org
sujaldev: Parsing is definitely hard at first! I've been deep in parsing for a long time (I wrote the CSS Syntax spec), so my difficulty judgement is a bit skewed. ^_^ Which should be an indicator of how hard layout is, tho.
do you have any suggestions on how I could make something simpler for the layout part? (assuming its possible)

content.body: I liked the suggestion (somewhere way above) to find out more about non-conforming layouts (e.g., from browsers like lynx)
https://github.com/mdn/content/issues/8486 could use help from somebody with good WebGL familiarity. Basically adding a few more sentences of explanatory text to an existing tutorial.

hsivonen: ok, yeah, speculative fetches from non-speculative parsing isn't news and the spec should allow for that to happen. I thought you asked for speculative *parsing* to be allowed without blocking <script>s
content.formatted_body: hsivonen: ok, yeah, speculative fetches from non-speculative parsing isn't news and the spec should allow for that to happen. I thought you asked for speculative parsing to be allowed without blocking <script>s

content.body: hsivonen: as for speculative fetches while looking for a meta charset... if we are to change the spec to run the tree builder while looking for meta charset, that would be more natural to spec speculative fetches
content.formatted_body: hsivonen: as for speculative fetches while looking for a meta charset... if we are to change the spec to run the tree builder while looking for meta charset, that would be more natural to spec speculative fetches

content.body: https://github.com/mdn/content/issues/8448 could use some help from somebody with good 2dcontext familiarity. Basically just needs a comment to confirm whether or not what the OP is asserting is actually correct.

Indeed.

content.body: Domenic: re: https://github.com/tc39/proposal-iterator-helpers/issues/122#issuecomment-909427809: I think it's actually `stream[Symbol.asyncIterator]().map(...)`, which suggests maybe streams (or all web-platform iterables?) ought to have a more conveniently named method which exposes the iterator
content.formatted_body: Domenic: re: https://github.com/tc39/proposal-iterator-helpers/issues/122#issuecomment-909427809: I think it's actually stream[Symbol.asyncIterator]().map(...), which suggests maybe streams (or all web-platform iterables?) ought to have a more conveniently named method which exposes the iterator

content.body: wait, unless there is such a method and I don't know about it
bakkot: ah yeah, you're right. The method is .values()
content.formatted_body: bakkot: ah yeah, you're right. The method is .values()
